job_title: Staff RN in Chester, NJ
pros: Very thorough orientation with experienced staff. Supportive management and good pay and benefits. Smaller organization so feels like family. Co workers are amazing. I would stay if I didn’t have to move.
cons: Scheduling can be hit or miss. System changes frequently. Company getting rid of admission nurses so workload can be very heavy.

job_title: Dietetic Technician in Marlton, NJ
pros: Flexible schedule majority of the time. Decent pay. Work is not too hard.
cons: Not enough staff, very unorganized, always scrambling for anyone to work there. I get my DTR credentials just for people who had no experience in a kitchen to be hired as a diet tech as well. Lots of issues between kitchen staff and the diet techs.

job_title: Food Service Associate in Saddle Brook, NJ
pros: Always a need for workers. Hours available.
cons: Low pay. No Healthcare. No progress to better paying positions.

job_title: Switchboard Operator/Receptionist in West Orange, NJ
pros:
Well known physical rehabilitation hospital
Good for advancing career in medical field
Decent pay for nurses, aides, therapists.
Clean facility
Multiple facilities (including 100 outpatient satellite locations)
cons:
Admin and management usually out for their own interests.
Low pay for other departments
Over working employees due to staffing issues in multiple departments 
No appreciation for small departments such as security, housekeeping, maintenance (usually the most critically understaffed departments) 
Admin including HR are unresponsive to some extent, ignoring certain things when it's not convenient for them. Have been caught lying about various policies.
Did not inform departments about covid-19 bonuses they were entitled to later claims " it was too much paperwork" meanwhile nurses got up to a 700$ bonus. 
Did not offer covid-19 sick time, or incentives. Screening process was changed too often and not communicated, making it difficult for staff and visitors to adhere.
No communication between departments
Hierarchy which makes this a toxic workplace, if you scrub toilets you will definitely feel like the bottom of the food chain.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Orange, NJ
pros: State of the art equipment, great learning opportunities working with TBI, SCI, stroke, amputation patients. Most coworkers are between 25-30 so it's easy to make friends and learn from one another. Senior staff on first and third floors are very nice and helpful.  Lots of PTO and scheduled days off for each weekend work day. Opportunity to work extra weekends/holidays for more money. Management has made a real effort in the past few years to make sure most sessions are individual which works for patients and therapists alike. Management is usually kind and supportive.
cons: Salary is very low , 401K contribution is weak as well. Many nursing aides treat patients rudely and keep them waiting far too long for basic human needs...some aides are phenomenal but all end up jaded after a while due to some people's negative energy. Only $500 per year to put toward continuing education..sometimes that's not even enough to cover one course for the year. PTO has to be requested 6-9 months in advance or else you're unlikely to be approved and if you are, it's the day before. Mandatory to work 2 weekend days per month. Some groups of staff members are very catty and spend hours gossiping in the offices because they have no lives or friends outside of work...these people make it difficult to concentrate on actual work and bring negativity to the workplace for no reason. Scheduling errors are an almost daily occurrence.  Room for growth but you will have to spend a lot of time getting rec letters and writing essays/building portfolio to apply for a basic promotion which still puts you below the avg therapist salary in the area.

job_title: Volunteer Yoga/Wellness Instructor in Lyndhurst, NJ
pros: This was a volunteer position so I did not have a supervisor to answer to, but the young lady in charge was extremely warm and helpful.  I taught Chair Yoga and meditation/relaxation techniques to individuals with brain injuries and their families/care givers.  Interacting with and getting to know these people was the best part of the job for me.  It was very humbling and made me feel grateful for all that I have. I thought I was providing something special for the patients, when in truth they gave me so much more.
cons: Some patients were difficult to manage and sometimes only a handful of patients would attend the session.  Also, there were times I went home feeling a bit sad because some of the injuries were severe and their stories were often heartbreaking.  I left wishing I could offer them more.

review_title: Learned a lot, but very high intensity and difficult to get time off.
job_title: Physical Therapist in Chester, NJ
pros: Part of a larger team. You get to learn a lot of skills. Great to put on your resume.
cons: They give you time off, but it is very difficult to get the days off you want. The usual is to have a 2 patient to 1 therapist ratio (unless doing brain injury) and this includes stroke patients, and sometimes it is difficult to jump back and forth between patients. Also, you can't get money towards continuing education until you have worked for at least a year.

review_title: Good people in the building but corporate doesn’t care
job_title: Registered Nurse in West Orange, NJ
pros: People who work their are dedicated.  They are kind and want what matters.... best care for the patient, best outcomes. They all work very hard.
cons: Select Medical is a money machine.  Their concern is not what is happening on the ground floor... cut back, cut back, save money.  Not the best way to run healthcare.  Higher ups  get on the bandwagon to protect themselves and advance their careers.

review_title: This place is only getting worse
job_title: Support Staff in West Orange, NJ
pros: 90% of your co-workers will be really good people. They will be the only thing keeping you from jumping off a cliff.
cons: TERRIBLE management. New managers and directors are running employee morale to the ground. People are quitting left and right. The pay is LOW. No chance for advancement. If you're a minority ,management will treat you like an incompetent child. If you work in house keeping or are an aide and especially if you're a minority you are treated like "the help" 1920s style by racist managers (who are ALL white btw)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Orange, NJ
pros: Great co-workers to be around working as a team to get through the day.
cons: No discount on food and drinks for employees. Only free coffee,  and free tea. One minute you're told to work as a team, and the next you're told to work alone. It's a lot of politics and a few workers who think they own the name Kessler.

job_title: Rehab Assistant in Chester, NJ
pros: Good coworkers and patients. Pay decent considering you don't need prior experience. Hours you want including overtime allowed. Full time allows for pto/sick days.
cons: Health insurance could be better for working in the healthcare field. Raises are only 2% max yearly. No bonuses. Can't move up unless you get a degree in something specific.

job_title: Rehabilitation Assistant in West Orange, NJ
pros: Some of the Coworkers are awesome, learn a few things from senior staff.
cons: Horrible Place to work and after reading these reviews more than clear HR is desperate enough to write their own reviews or the few that did review are the favored group. The patients are awesome if you treat them right but complaints that come from them often is that the place is dirty, the equipment is outdated and often noisy, the linens have stains and holes, they are charged for services and items they didn't receive, the list goes on. For staffing if you are Full Time they will under staff in hopes that you can come in and do the extra work in double shifts or that you will give up your days off to fill in where they clearly should've staffed. If you are Per Diem good luck getting days to work whether you put in a schedule or not you will always come last to a Full Timers double or a Agency Sitter you will even be cancelled after already arriving to work so that they can stay or come in so you have been warned. The favored few Per Diems will rack up all the hours available doing doubles every single day if allowed and when you look for a few hours there are none. The Management is a piece of work doesn't matter how hard you work they are never watching unless you agree to be their pet and fetch things for them and go above and beyond to please them or you have refused to do what I just mentioned making you a target to which case hold on for the repeated calls from HR for everything from breathing to existing. HR will always side with them no matter what you do or what proof you have they kind of have a thing for firing people left and right especially with their newly acquired HR Rep. For the sake of not writing a book I will end it here but if you want to keep your licenses and certifications steer clear go somewhere that takes their line of work and your careers seriously.
